p: It is interesting to note the emergence of ‘decentralisation’ and the inclusion of ‘political will’. With respect to decentralisation, Chile is a centralised country where the Metropolitan region is the political power, home to the leading national institutions, and where most important decisions are made. This situation has been claimed historically by citizen and politicians of other regions. Although there has been an effort to decentralise undertaken by the central government, for example, the creation of Los Ríos region in 2007, this effort is perceived as weak. Regions continue to demand more independence, considering this factor as determinant of their limited development (Montecinos 2005; Waissbluth et al. 2007). For this reason, it is not strange that this aspect will be important in Los Ríos and Biobío, but absent in the Metropolitan region.
